hawaiian_text: Ho'ouna maila 'o 'Ama'u ke ali'i mai Waikīkī mai, 'ehā po'e kaua, aia ma ka po'e ho'okahi he kanahā kumamāwalu kānaka ka nui, pēlā ā pau nā po'e 'ehā. A hiki lākou ma ke kula o Keahumoa, komo lākou ā loko o ka hale, 'a'ohe kanaka. A mākaukau lākou e ho'i, kāhea mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i luna o kaupoku. A lohe lākou i ka leo, 'a'ohe na'e he 'ike 'ia o ke kino, nīnau aku lākou: "'Auhea 'oe e wala'au nei?" 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Eia nō wau i luna nei." Pi'i a'ela 'ewalu kānaka, 'ehā ma ke kua o ka hale, 'ehā ma ke alo o ka hale ā loa'a 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o. 'Ī mai 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "He aha mai nei kā 'oukou o 'one'i?" 'Ī aku lākou: "I hele mai nei mākou e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o, he wahi keiki 'u'uku e like me 'oe, he ikaika a me ke koa loa, nāna nō i pepehi i kona makua kāne, 'o Puali'i."
gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_translation: 'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four warriors. Each group contained eighty people, totaling that number for all four groups. They arrived at the plains of Keahumoa and entered the house, but no one was there. As they were preparing to leave, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from above the rafters. They heard a voice, but could not see anyone. They asked, "Where are you calling from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied, “I am here above.” Eight men climbed up—four to the back of the house and four to the front—and found Nāmakaokapāo'o. He said, “What do you want?” They replied, "We have come to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o—a little boy like you, who is strong and brave, the one who killed his stepfather, Puali'i.”
gemma-3-27b-it-qat-mlx-maui_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
'Ama'u, the chief from Waikīkī, sent four warriors. Each group contained eighty people, totaling that number for all four groups. They arrived at the plains of Keahumoa and entered the house, but no one was there. As they were preparing to leave, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from above the rafters. They heard a voice, but could not see anyone. They asked, "Where are you calling from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o replied, “I am here above.” Eight men climbed up—four to the back of the house and four to the front—and found Nāmakaokapāo'o. He said, “What do you want?” They replied, "We have come to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o—a little boy like you, who is strong and brave, the one who killed his stepfather, Puali'i.”
</translation>

<commentary>
• This paragraph marks a turning point in the narrative, introducing direct conflict and revealing the reason for Nāmakaokapāo'o’s notoriety. The arrival of 'Ama'u’s warriors signifies an attempt to bring retribution for Puali'i’s death, likely orchestrated by a larger political power structure. The sheer number of warriors (320 total) suggests a significant mobilization, indicating Puali'i held considerable status or that 'Ama'u intends to make a strong example of Nāmakaokapāo'o.

– **'Ama'u:** This name – 'A-mau (to be steadfast, to hold firm) – is significant. It suggests a chief who is resolute and unwavering in his decisions, likely someone who values order and control. The name etymology hints at a chief determined to maintain the status quo, even if it means resorting to force.

– **The Warriors & Numbers:** The number 80 is interesting and likely symbolic. In Hawaiian cosmology, numbers often hold deeper meaning beyond simple quantification. 80 could represent a complete unit or cycle (though less common than numbers like 4, 7, or 13). The repetition of the number (four groups of eighty) emphasizes the scale of the operation.

• **The Setting – Keahumoa:** The plains of Keahumoa (heap of chickens) are again referenced. This location continues to be central to the narrative, potentially representing a liminal space—a place between worlds or states of being. The name itself could symbolize abundance (chickens representing food and prosperity) but also vulnerability (chickens being easily preyed upon).

– The description of the house being empty is significant. It suggests Nāmakaokapāo'o is either incredibly skilled at hiding or possesses some form of supernatural ability. It also creates a sense of unease and anticipation, foreshadowing the confrontation to come.

• **Nāmakaokapāo'o’s Voice & Location:** Nāmakaokapāo'o calling out from “above the rafters” (kaupoku) is a key detail. This suggests he is not only hiding but also occupying a position of power—literally looking down on his adversaries. The rafters themselves could symbolize the structure of society or the ancestral lineage—Nāmakaokapāo'o is positioned within this framework, challenging it from the inside.

– The warriors’ inability to see Nāmakaokapāo'o despite hearing his voice could indicate he is cloaked in some form of invisibility or possesses a spirit presence. This reinforces his supernatural abilities and adds to the mystery surrounding his character.

• **The Accusation & Motivation:** The warriors’ accusation—that Nāmakaokapāo'o killed his stepfather, Puali'i—reveals the central conflict driving the narrative. The description of Nāmakaokapāo'o as a “little boy” (keiki 'u'uku) who is “strong and brave” (ikaika a me ke koa loa) highlights the contrast between his physical appearance and his actions.

– The reference to Puali'i’s death is crucial. It suggests that Nāmakaokapāo'o has disrupted the established order by killing a figure of authority. This could be interpreted as an act of rebellion against the 'Ai Kapu system or a challenge to the traditional power structure. The warriors’ emphasis on Nāmakaokapāo'o’s youth suggests they underestimate his capabilities, setting the stage for a potential upset. The entire scenario echoes themes of *kapu* breaking and the consequences thereof, common in Hawaiian oral traditions. The warriors' statement is likely a simplification of events, designed to demonize Nāmakaokapāo'o and justify their actions. The narrative is likely presenting a more nuanced picture of the events, with Nāmakaokapāo'o’s actions potentially motivated by a desire to dismantle oppressive practices or protect his people.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Chief 'Ama'u sent four regiments of soldiers from Waikīkī totalling forty-eight men. When they reached the plains of Keahumoa, they entered the house, but no one was there. When they were ready to return back to Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo'o called out from on top of the roof. They heard the voice, but didn't see any body, and they asked, "Where is that voice coming from?" Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I'm up here." Eight men climbed up, four men went onto the roof and four on the face of the house and got a hold of Nāmakaokapāo'o. Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "What in the world are you all doing here?" They said, "We came to fight Nāmakaokapāo'o, a little boy like you, who is really strong and brave. He killed his father, Puali'i."
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
